title: Kehkashan Basu
text:
Kehkashan Basu (born June 5, 2000) is an environmental and human rights activist from the <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a>. Basu also advocates for peace, children’s rights, education for sustainable development, nuclear disarmament, gender equality and <a href="climate%20justice">climate justice</a>. She is the Founder-President of Green Hope Foundation, the youngest Councillor of World Future Council, the youngest Trustee of the Parliament of the World's Religions, a <a href="KidsRights">KidsRights</a> Youngsters member, and winner of the <a href="International%20Children%27s%20Peace%20Prize">International Children's Peace Prize</a> 2016.
Biography.
Kehkashan was born on June 5. At age 8, she was planting trees and organizing young people to <a href="recycle">recycle</a>. At age 11, she addressed the TUNZA Children and Youth Conference in Indonesia, and the next year she set a record as the youngest delegate to speak at a <a href="press%20conference">press conference</a> at the <a href="United%20Nations%20Conference%20on%20Sustainable%20Development">United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development</a> (Rio+20).
She founded the Green Hope Foundation in 2012, with the goal of teaching and implementing the UN's <a href="Sustainable%20Development%20Goals">Sustainable Development Goals</a> (SDGs) including through <a href="grassroots">grassroots</a> action such as <a href="tree%20planting">tree planting</a>. The organization also involves young people globally in the SDGs through community-focused projects in climate justice, halting land degradation, promoting sustainable consumption and renewable energy, and conserving biodiversity, as well as gender equality and social justice. Currently with more than 3000 members in total, across <a href="Canada">Canada</a>, <a href="Suriname">Suriname</a>, <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a>, <a href="Oman">Oman</a>, <a href="Qatar">Qatar</a>, <a href="Bahrain">Bahrain</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>, <a href="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>, <a href="Australia">Australia</a>, <a href="Kenya">Kenya</a>, <a href="The%20Bahamas">The Bahamas</a>, <a href="Chile">Chile</a>, <a href="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, <a href="Seychelles">Seychelles</a>, <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a>, <a href="Netherlands">The Netherlands</a>, <a href="Democratic%20Republic%20of%20the%20Congo">Democratic Republic of the Congo</a>, <a href="Peru">Peru</a>, <a href="Sri%20Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>, <a href="India">India</a>, <a href="Nepal">Nepal</a>, <a href="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, <a href="Kiribati">Kiribati</a> and <a href="Liberia">Liberia</a>, the organization works by conducting workshops and conferences around the implementation of the SDGs.
Basu attended the Deira International School in Dubai. She moved to Canada to study and December 2020 was a third-year student at the <a href="University%20of%20Toronto">University of Toronto</a> majoring in <a href="environmental%20studies">environmental studies</a> and minoring in <a href="gender%20studies">gender studies</a> and physical and environmental geography.
In 2017, she published the short story book "The Tree of Hope", in collaboration with the illustrator Karen Webb-Meek. In the book, a young girl creates an <a href="oasis">oasis</a> in a desert by planting trees and persuading friends to help.
